chapter.title: Dependency injection and programmatic lookup
chapter.para: One of the most significant features of CDI — certainly the most recognized — is typesafe dependency injection.

section.title: Injection points
section.para: The @Inject annotation lets us define an injection point that is injected during bean instantiation. Injection can occur through three different mechanisms.

listitem.para: A bean can only have one injectable constructor.
A bean can have multiple initializer methods. If the bean is a session bean, the initializer method is not required to be a business method of the session bean.
Unlike with JSF managed beans, getter and setter methods are not required for field injection to work.

section.para: Dependency injection always occurs when the bean instance is first instantiated by the container. Simplifying just a little, things happen in this order:

listitem.para: First, the container calls the bean constructor (the default constructor or the one annotated @Inject), to obtain an instance of the bean.
Next, the container initializes the values of all injected fields of the bean.
Next, the container calls all initializer methods of the bean.

important.para: This call order is not portable. Do not rely on a specific order.

listitem.para: Finally, the @PostConstruct method, if any, is called.

section.para: Note that the container may call initializer methods declared by a superclass before initializing injected fields declared by a subclass.

note.para: One major advantage of constructor injection is that it allows the bean to be immutable.

section.para: CDI also supports parameter injection for some other methods that are invoked by the container. For instance, parameter injection is supported for producer methods:
In this case, the @Inject annotation is not required at the injection point. The same is true for observer methods (which we'll meet in ) and disposer methods.

section.title: What gets injected
section.para: The CDI specification defines a typesafe resolution procedure that the container follows when identifying the bean to inject to an injection point. Typesafe resolution is performed at system initialization time, which means that the container will inform the developer immediately if a bean's dependencies cannot be satisfied.
The purpose of this algorithm is to allow multiple beans to implement the same bean type and either:

listitem.para: allow the client to select which implementation it requires using a qualifier, or
allow the application deployer to select which implementation is appropriate for a particular deployment, without changes to the client, by enabling or disabling an alternative, or
allow the beans to be isolated into separate modules.

section.para: Obviously, if you have exactly one bean of a given type, and an injection point with that same type, then bean A is going to go into slot A. This is the simplest possible scenario. Your first applications will likely have lots of these.
But then, things start to get complicated. Let's explore how the container determines which bean to inject in more advanced cases. We'll start by taking a closer look at qualifiers.

Qualifier annotations can also qualify method arguments of producer, disposer and observer methods. Combining qualified arguments with producer methods is a good way to select an implementation of a bean type at runtime, based on system state:
If an injected field or a parameter of a bean constructor or initializer method is not explicitly annotated with a qualifier, the default qualifier, @Default, is assumed.

Using qualifiers differs from specifying an implementation class in that qualifiers do not create a direct dependency to any particular implementation. A qualifier is like an extension of the interface; there can be multiple alternative implementations of @Asynchronous PaymentProcessor.

section.title: The built-in qualifiers @Default and @Any
section.para: Whenever a bean or injection point does not explicitly declare a qualifier, the container assumes the qualifier @Default. From time to time, you'll need to decare an injection point without specifying a qualifier. There's a qualifier for that too. All beans have the qualifier @Any. By explicitly specifying @Any at an injection point, you suppress the default qualifier, without otherwise restricting the beans that are eligible for injection.
This is especially useful if you want to iterate over all beans with a certain bean type, for example:

section.title: Qualifiers with members
section.para: Java annotations can have members. Annotation members can be used to further discriminate a qualifier. This prevents a potential explosion of new annotations. For example, instead of creating several qualifiers representing different payment methods, we could aggregate them into a single annotation with a member:
Then we select one of the possible member values when appling the qualifier:
section.programlisting: private @Inject @PayBy(CHECK) PaymentProcessor checkPayment;
section.para: We can force the container to ignore a member of a qualifier type by annotating the member @Nonbinding.

section.title: Multiple qualifiers
section.para: An injection point may specify multiple qualifiers:
section.programlisting: @Inject @Synchronous @Reliable PaymentProcessor syncPaymentProcessor;
section.para: Then only a bean which has both qualifier annotations would be eligible for injection.

section.title: Alternatives
section.para: Alternatives are beans whose implementation is specific to a particular client module or deployment scenario. The following alternative defines a mock implementation of both @Synchronous PaymentProcessor and @Asynchronous PaymentProcessor, all in one:

By default, @Alternative beans are disabled. We need to enable an alternative in the beans.xml descriptor of a bean archive to make it available for instantiation and injection. This activation only applies to the beans in that archive.
section.programlisting: <beans xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation=" http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee/beans_1_0.xsd"> <alternatives> <class>org.mycompany.mock.MockPaymentProcessor</class> </alternatives> </beans>
section.para: When an ambiguous dependency exists at an injection point, the container attempts to resolve the ambiguity by looking for an enabled alternative among the beans that could be injected. If there is exactly one enabled alternative, then that alternative bean will be injected.

section.title: Fixing unsatisfied and ambiguous dependencies
section.para: The typesafe resolution algorithm fails when, after considering the qualifier annotations on all beans that implement the bean type of an injection point and filtering out disabled beans (@Alternative beans which are not explicitly enabled), the container is unable to identify exactly one bean to inject. The container will abort deployment, informing us of the unsatisfied or ambiguous dependency.
During the course of your development, you're going to encounter this situation. Let's learn how to resolve it.
To fix an unsatisfied dependency, either:

listitem.para: create a bean which implements the bean type and has all the qualifier types of the injection point,
make sure that the bean you already have is in the classpath of the module with the injection point, or
explicitly enable an @Alternative bean that implements the bean type and has the appropriate qualifier types, using beans.xml.

section.para: To fix an ambiguous dependency, either:

listitem.para: introduce a qualifier to distinguish between the two implementations of the bean type,
disable one of the beans by annotating it @Alternative,
move one of the implementations to a module that is not in the classpath of the module with the injection point, or
disable one of two @Alternative beans that are trying to occupy the same space, using beans.xml.

section.para: See this FAQ for step-by-step instructions for how to resolve an ambigous resolution exception between a raw bean type and a producer method that returns the same bean type.
On the other hand, if you really do have an optional or multivalued injection point, you should change the type of your injection point to Instance. You can find more information in .
Now there's one more issue you need to be aware of when using the dependency injection service.

section.title: Client proxies
section.para: Clients of an injected bean do not usually hold a direct reference to a bean instance, unless the bean is a dependent object (scoped with the @Dependent annotation).

Imagine that a bean bound to the application scope holds a direct reference to a bean bound to the request scope. The application-scoped bean is shared between many different requests. However, each request should see a different instance of the request scoped bean — the current one!

Now imagine that a bean bound to the session scope holds a direct reference to a bean bound to the application scope. From time to time, the session context is serialized to disk in order to use memory more efficiently. However, the application scoped bean instance should not be serialized along with the session scoped bean. The application can retrieve the reference at any time, so there is no need to store it.

Therefore, unless a bean has the default scope @Dependent, the container must direct all injected references to the bean through a proxy object. This client proxy ensures that the bean instance that receives a method invocation is the instance that is associated with the current context. The client proxy also allows beans bound to contexts such as the session context to be serialized to disk without recursively serializing other injected beans.
The following Java types cannot be proxied by the container:

listitem.para: classes without a non-private constructor with no parameters,
classes which are declared final or have a final method, and
arrays and primitive types.

section.para: You might come across an unproxyable dependency problem. These are easily fixed. If an injection point of type X results in an unproxyable dependency, simply:

listitem.para: add a constructor with no parameters to X,
change the type of the injection point to Instance<X>,
introduce an interface Y, implemented by the injected bean, and change the type of the injection point to Y, or
if all else fails, change the scope of the injected bean to @Dependent.

note.para: A future release of Weld will likely support a non-standard workaround for this limitation, using non-portable JVM APIs:

listitem.para: Sun, IcedTea, Mac: Unsafe.allocateInstance() (The most efficient)
IBM, JRockit: ReflectionFactory.newConstructorForSerialization()

note.para: However, this has not yet been implemented.

section.title: Obtaining a contextual instance by programmatic lookup
section.para: In certain situations, injection is not the best way to obtain a contextual reference. For example, it can't be used when:

listitem.para: the bean type or qualifiers vary dynamically at runtime,
there is no bean which satisfies the type and qualifiers, or
we would like to iterate over all beans of a certain type.

section.para: In these situations, the application can obtain an instance of the Instance interface, parameterized for the bean type, by injection:
section.programlisting: @Inject Instance<PaymentProcessor> paymentProcessorSource;
section.para: The get() method of Instance produces a contextual instance of the bean.
section.programlisting: PaymentProcessor p = paymentProcessorSource.get();
section.para: Qualifiers can be specified in one of two ways:

listitem.para: by annotating the Instance injection point, or
by passing qualifiers to the select() of Event.

section.para: Specifying the qualifiers at the injection point is simpler:
section.programlisting: @Inject @Asynchronous Instance<PaymentProcessor> paymentProcessorSource;
section.para: Now, the PaymentProcessor returned by get() will have the qualifier @Asynchronous.
Alternatively, we can specify the qualifier dynamically. First, we add the @Any qualifier to the injection point, to suppress the default qualifier. (All beans have the qualifier @Any.)
section.programlisting: @Inject @Any Instance<PaymentProcessor> paymentProcessorSource;
section.para: Next, we need to obtain an instance of our qualifier type. Since annotatons are interfaces, new Asynchronous() is incorrect. Creating a concrete implementation of an annotation type from scratch is tedious. CDI lets us obtain a qualifier instance by giving the helper class AnnotationLiteral a subclass:
section.programlisting: abstract class AsynchronousQualifier extends AnnotationLiteral<Asynchronous> implements Asynchronous {}
section.para: In some cases, we can use an anonymous class:
section.programlisting: PaymentProcessor p = paymentProcessorSource .select(new AnnotationLiteral<Asynchronous>() {});
section.para: However, we can't use an anonymous class to implement a qualifier type with members.
Now, finally, we can pass the qualifier to the select() method of Instance.

section.title: The InjectionPoint object
section.para: There are certain kinds of dependent objects (beans with the @Dependent scope) that need to know something about the object or injection point into which they are injected, in order to perform their function. Some such objects are:

listitem.para: the log category for a Logger, which depends upon the class of the object that owns it;
an injected HTTP parameter or header value, which depends on the parameter or header name specified at the injection point; and
an injected EL expression evaluation result, which depends on the expression specified at the injection point.

section.para: A dependent bean can inject an instance of InjectionPoint and access metadata relating to the injection point to which it belongs.
Let's look at an example. The following code is verbose, and vulnerable to refactoring problems:

This lets us write the following, instead of the initial verbose code:
